posts.name:
Brad Federman
Brad Federman
posts.content:
"I am not feeling confident. All of these employers are asking for years of experience, expertise, certifications, and more. I am getting out of what I am doing because technology and AI have reduced the amount of work available. I was hoping to transition to something else and I am not seeing that possibility. What am I going to do?"

She woke up one morning, scrolling through job postings, and feeling that pit in her stomach. The requirements seem impossible: years of experience, endless certifications, and expertise you don‚Äôt have. Imagine realizing that the work you‚Äôve built your life around is disappearing‚Äîreplaced by technology and AI. What would you do?

That was the raw, emotional email I received from someone grappling with this very reality. They‚Äôre watching their opportunities vanish and feeling utterly stuck. And here‚Äôs the hard truth: they‚Äôre not alone.

We are living in a brave new world. Change isn‚Äôt just coming; it‚Äôs here, and it‚Äôs relentless. The numbers are staggering:

Goldman Sachs estimates 300 million jobs will vanish because of AI.
Forbes predicts that 50% of jobs could be displaced within just three years.
In May alone, 4,000 people in tech lost their jobs to AI (Business Insider).

Some may argue these numbers are exaggerated, but we can all agree: the landscape of work is shifting beneath our feet. As roles disappear, competition intensifies. Employers demand more‚Äîmore skills, more adaptability, more innovation.

So, here‚Äôs the question: Are you ready?

This isn‚Äôt the time for comfort zones. We live in the age of growth, where success favors those willing to adapt, learn, and evolve. Every day is an opportunity to:

Master new skills. Stay curious and committed to growth.
Embrace technology. AI isn‚Äôt just a threat; it‚Äôs a tool‚Äîif you know how to use it.
Get uncomfortable. Growth lives on the edge of discomfort.

The alternative? Waking up one day with no options, desperate for a lifeline.

That‚Äôs a reality none of us can afford.

Let‚Äôs shift the narrative. Let‚Äôs prepare. Share your thoughts‚Äîwhat are you doing to stand out and stay ahead? If you‚Äôve been impacted, how are you navigating this shift? Let‚Äôs talk about it, together.

comments.commentText: Mary McConner, Ph.D., CDE¬Æ Michael Bruno SHRM-Memphis SHRM-UofM Student Chapter CHRISTINE Heath ESSARY Would love to get your thoughts and insights.

Great post, Brad Federman. While many employers are helping their teams level up and stay relevant, many others do not. I think HR teams are overwhelmed and are not prioritizing AI competency, for example. To me, the lesson is crystal clear: it's up to each of us to make sure we are staying current and relevant.
Mike, I could not agree with you more. Level Up! Everyday!

posts.name:
Neil Sarkar
Neil Sarkar
posts.content:
Over 90% of manufacturers are investing in digital tools. If you‚Äôre not, let‚Äôs face it‚Äîyou‚Äôre falling behind.

As a SaaS founder, here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned: digital transformation isn‚Äôt a trend‚Äîit‚Äôs survival.

I once had a client say, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve done it this way for decades; why change?‚Äù Then their competitor launched a digital ordering system, cut turnaround times by 50%, and‚Äîwell, you can guess who their customers called.
What Does Digital Transformation Really Mean?

1Ô∏è‚É£ Automating repetitive tasks ‚Äì Focus on what truly matters.
2Ô∏è‚É£ Integrating data systems ‚Äì Say goodbye to silos and hello to real-time insights.
3Ô∏è‚É£ Embracing predictive tools ‚Äì AI can predict when machines will fail before they actually do.

‚ÄúBut Neil, isn‚Äôt this expensive?‚Äù Doing nothing costs more. Downtime, inefficiencies, missed opportunities‚Äîthey all drain your bottom line.
Start small. Pick a pilot project. Involve your team. Bite-sized wins lead to big results.

At, I‚Äôve seen clients cut manual reporting by 80% with just one shift. That‚Äôs not just helpful‚Äîit‚Äôs a game changer.

TAKEAWAY:
Standing still isn‚Äôt safe‚Äîit‚Äôs risky. So here‚Äôs your challenge: take one small step this week.
If this resonates, drop a comment or DM me. Let‚Äôs chat about your digital transformation journey‚Äîwhat‚Äôs working, what‚Äôs not, and where to start.
Don‚Äôt wait for change to catch you‚Äîbe the one leading it.

posts.name:
Kevin "KD" Dorsey
Kevin "KD" Dorsey
posts.content:
You‚Äôd be shocked how much work you could get done at work if all you did at work was work‚Ä¶

I say this often.

Not only to myself but also my leaders and team.

We live in a DISTRACTED world.

100s of emails per day.

100s of slacks per day.

100s of notifications per day.

Algorithms that literally know us better than ourselves and are fine tuned to keep us coming back.

Eliminate distractions to the best of your ability.

I used an app called Opal for my phone to set limits on apps and it locks you out.

I do not have push notifications for email on my phone.

I routinely shut down slack during focused work times

The more you can ELIMINATE the distractions the better.

Trying to avoid them requires will power.

We only have so much of that.

Get your work done at work so you don‚Äôt have to work outside of work.

Unless you want to live the life of the great philosopher Rhianna

Work work work work work work‚Ä¶.

comments.commentText: You‚Äôve nailed it here, less noise at work means more time for actual life outside of it Kevin "KD" Dorsey

posts.name:
Katie A.
Katie A.
posts.content:
These are the BEST things I‚Äôve GAINED from owning a startup: ‚Äç

And nope none of them have anything to do with money!!

Over the past 4 years of running my business, I‚Äôve come to realise how much I‚Äôve grown‚Äîand I mean seriously GROWN. It‚Äôs been such a journey of self-improvement and skill-building, and I honestly wouldn‚Äôt trade it for anything. Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve learned:

‚è∞ Time management
This one has been a game-changer. Figuring out how to manage my time well has helped me handle ALL the things without losing my mind. Every minute counts when you‚Äôre running the show, and I‚Äôve learned how to make it WORK. Highly rate time blocking!! ‚ÄçÔ∏è

 Self-confidence
A HUGE one for me!!! I struggled so much with confidence when I was younger and it‚Äôs crazy how much my business has changed that for me!! Taking charge of a company, making decisions, and learning to trust myself‚Äîit‚Äôs forced me out of my comfort zone and forced to build self confidence

 Problem-solving skills
Simply said if you‚Äôre running a startup, you‚Äôre going to make mistakes. So MANY mistakes. But honestly, that‚Äôs the job‚Äîsolving problems nonstop. My company wouldn‚Äôt be here today if I hadn‚Äôt learned how to face challenges head-on all the time

Ô∏è Communication skills
This one‚Äôs non-negotiable. If you can‚Äôt communicate clearly and effectively, your business is in trouble. I‚Äôve had to get really intentional about how I communicate‚Äîespecially since I love to chat (aka ‚Äúwaffle on‚Äù ). Learning to be concise has been a game-changer.

 Resilience
This one‚Äôs a MUST because running a business is NOT easy, and there have been so many moments where I felt like giving up. But building resilience has helped me push through the hard days and keep going. (Which is always worth it may I add) Sometimes, success is just about not quitting when it feels impossible.

What about you? What lessons has your work or life journey taught you? Share them below‚ÄîI‚Äôd love to hear! 

And make sure to REPOST this!! Ô∏è

comments.commentText:

posts.name:
Steve Litzow
Steve Litzow
posts.content:
Big deal about to close... but it‚Äôs not the ICP?

When I work on refining sales strategies for scale ups, I always include a validation step.

It comes after the proposal and negotiation.

It‚Äôs an internal step for:
‚Äì The CEO or VP of Sales to review the deal.
‚Äì The SDR or sales manager to self-analyze.
‚Äì An item to discuss during weekly or monthly deal reviews.

The key focus of validation?

Double-check the customer still fits your ICP.

It‚Äôs overlooked because:
‚Äì The SDR wants to hit quota.
‚Äì The sales manager wants to hit quota.
‚Äì Or simply, the revenue is too tempting to resist.

But if you‚Äôre serious about scaling to 8 or 9 figures, you must take this step.

You must reconsider going ahead if the ICP isn‚Äôt the right fit.

Here‚Äôs why‚Ä¶

I recently read a story from Jake Fuentes, co-founder of Cascade, about why he shut his startup down.

He admitted that ‚ÄúICP fray‚Äù was a key factor.

Cascade initially defined their ICP as ‚Äúnontechnical business analysts using Excel to crunch big data sets‚Äù.

The definition was too broad.

They ended up chasing customers with wildly different use cases:
‚Äì A scooter company managing location data.
‚Äì An HR team managing employee data.

They didn‚Äôt have a framework to accept or reject opportunities, so they tried to support them all.

Jake described this as ‚Äúa slow death of a thousand cuts.‚Äù

Supporting anyone and everyone pulled the company in a million directions, ultimately diluting their focus and stunting growth.

If you want to scale successfully, rejecting deals from prospects who don‚Äôt fit your ICP is the tough but necessary way forward.

Validate every deal.

Stick to your guns.

Keep closing.

Like what you read? Ô∏è Repost it to your network and follow Steve Litzow for more.

Want to accelerate your sales? Join our community of CEOs & Sales Leaders subscribers today:

comments.commentText: Staying true to your ICP is crucial for growth. Misaligned deals might boost short-term revenue but often lead to inefficiencies and lost focus. Discipline here pays dividends!

posts.name:
nick stagge üí≠
nick stagge üí≠
posts.content:
Looking back, I wouldn't have spent a single day in college. 
Unless you want to become a dr or a lawyer, it just doesn't add up.


Had I ditched college, I would have avoided:
- massive debt
- learning theory without application
- a lot of parking tickets
- working part time jobs that paid little & gave my minimal experience


Instead, I wish I would have secured an internship with a strong business leader, started my own business, traveled the world, or just enjoyed being young.

Had I done that, I could have...
- gained real-world work experience much faster
- built my professional network earlier
- made more money in the short (and long) term
- experienced new things outside my bubble
- figured out what I actually wanted to do with my career earlier


Is this just me?
Doubtful.

comments.commentText:
I think this is an feeling shared by a lot of people. However, just to play devils advocate a bit. 

- Without college, at least for designers in general, you miss out on learning the ins and outs of your craft surrounded by other designers who are learning with you guided by a professor actively working in the field.

- You miss out on learning the history, while boring at times, is important when wanting to understand what will stand the test of time and what will appear dated, even though it might look cool to you.

- looking back on my work before college, I had been designing for around 2-3 years. I was no good. Sure time would have allowed me to be better but I feel I experienced significant growth by rubbing shoulders with older students and alumni that in return pushed me to do more because I saw they could do it.

- I also have been exposed to forums, books, professionals, and other resources because of my time in college.

If I didn‚Äôt go to college, here are my questions:

- would I have really pushed myself to get better in a vacuum or was it the unspoken competition of class that helped me to grow?

- would I have secured any kind of design job/internship? Or would I have lost out on those opportunities‚Ä¶

Bryson King SLC Design and Wine, Creative Mornings, Design Mob, SL Deaign Week ‚Äî there are lots of places to meet up with other creatives, learn your craft, discuss the history, etc etc. 

Not to mention ‚Äî YouTube.

College is quite inexpensive for Utah residents. I believe it‚Äôs the cheapest in the nation. I went in state in Colorado and it was amazing. I still have professors I keep in touch with 23 years later. Friends with whom I share networking leads with. 

I got to play IM sports, lead Bible Studies, work a part time job, learn about failure, and still get in a lot of snowboarding.

We lack coming of age moments in our pluralistic society and I think the 4 year college experience is one of the few we have left.

Pew research did a study and 48% of college grads with debt make over $100k a year while on 14% of non college grads make over $100k. 64% of those without debt and a degree make over $100k.

Still worth it from my perspective
Adam Peek my shot is uglier than Sam Cassel.
